concept.title: Recommendations for the xml:lang attribute
concept.shortdesc: Specifying the xml:lang attribute in the DITA source facilitates translation and helps ensure that processors will handle content appropriately. Accordingly, this specification makes certain recommendations for best practises for where the xml:lang attribute should be set.

conbody.p: Setting the xml:lang attribute in the source-language document facilitates the translation process. It enables translation tools to simply change the value of the existing xml:lang attribute to the value of the target language. Since some translation tools do not support adding new markup to the document that is being translated, if source language content does not set the xml:lang attribute, it might be difficult or impossible for the translator to add the xml:lang attribute to the translated document.

In addition, setting the xml:lang attribute in the DITA source ensures that processors handle content in a language- and locale-appropriate way. If the xml:lang attribute is not set, processors might assume a default value which is inappropriate for the DITA content.
The following table outlines the recommended use of the xml:lang attribute in topics and maps. These recommendations ensure that DITA resources have a effective default language.

strow.stentry: DITA topic document that contains a single language
Specify the xml:lang attribute on the root element of the topic.
DITA topic document that contains more than one language

Specify the primary language and locale that applies to the topic on the highest-level element that contains content. If part of a topic is written in a different language, enclose that content in an element with the xml:lang attribute set appropriately. This applies to both block and inline elements that use the alternate language.
Specify the xml:lang attribute on the root element of the map. This applies both to the root map and any submaps.
